Award.AwardTitle: Theoretical Studies of Spectroscopic Line Mixing in Remote Sensing Applications with Theoretical Support to Improve the Accuracy of the HITRAN H2O Database
Award.AbstractNarration:
The HITRAN (high-resolution transmission) molecular absorption database currently contains some 7.4 million spectral lines of some 47 different molecular species (https://www.cfa.harvard.edu/hitran/ )
As such, along with appropriate computer codes, it can be used to accurately calculate the spectroscopic properties (transmission and emission) of light in the terrestrial (and other planetary) atmospheres. The HITRAN database is widely used by thousands of scientists and engineers, tackling a large range of scientific problems and interests.

This project has two stated objectives namely : (1) continuing studying theoretical and computational treatment of line mixing for molecules that are important in remote sensing and spectroscopy, and , (2) providing theoretical support for improving the accuracy of the HITRAN database, in particular calculation of H2O lineshapes. The first objective is based on prior NSF support to develop a formalism capable of studying line mixing from interactions between a molecular absorber and molecular perturbers. The second objective represents continuing effort to improve the accuracy of spectroscopic parameters of H2O lineshapes in spectral databases, specifically HITRAN, and related compilations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Retrieval of information from space and ground-based measurements and the ability to perform climate and atmospheric modeling require accurate and reliable knowledge of the spectroscopic parameters of important molecules in atmosphere whose spectra cover the entire spectrum from the microwave to the ultraviolet. Each of these molecular species contributes literally thousands or even millions of spectral lines. A full and complete knowledge of these lines, including how their intensities and shapes vary with the temperature and pressure of the atmospheric environment, is crucial in all of these applications. Meanwhile, there are many cases where the spectra are not solely determined by individual molecular lines. These events result from so-called line mixing, i.e., a collision-induced spectroscopic phenomenon which occurs when collisions between two molecules cause redistribution of line intensity of the absorber molecules thereby dramatically changing their spectral distributions. Thus, accurate knowledge of line mixing for these molecules is also crucial, especially in spectrally resolved remote sensing applications.

In order to meet users’ requirements, great experimental and theoretical efforts have been carried out by many research groups around the world over the past half of century. Given the fact that there are millions and millions molecular lines, to measure all of them is not realistic. In addition, measurements can’t be performed at some temperatures and pressures of interest in applications. Hence, line shape theories play an important role for providing the necessary information. Unfortunately, so far there are still no satisfactory theories available that can fully meet all of the spectroscopic requirements.

For example, with respect to some important spectroscopic parameters, one of the line shape theories (i.e., the Robert-Bonamy formalism) has be commonly used to calculate these parameters for the past 39 years and the calculated results have been adopted in main databases. Despite many improvements of this formalism, its main weaknesses remain unaddressed. In many cases, calculated results don’t match measurements well. Concerning with line mixing, for relatively complex molecular systems, there are no “first principle” calculations in existence, and the Robert-Bonamy formalism mentioned above completely fails to address it. As a result, one has to rely on the use of some semi-empirical models involving adjustable parameters.

We have studied line shape theories for three decades, and the current project represents our recent efforts to improve line shape theories. By carefully scrutinizing the theoretical basis of the Robert-Bonamy formalism, we have found that one of its main weaknesses arises from the application of an invalid approximation and the latter can be avoided. By removing this approximation, we have developed a better and more capable formalism which enables one to not only reduce uncertainties of the calculated spectroscopic parameters, but also to calculate the effects from line mixing. The method has been successfully applied for several important molecules in atmosphere including nitrogen, carbon dioxide, acetylene, ammonia, and water vapor. In comparison with that obtained from the Robert-Bonamy formalism, the newly calculated spectroscopic parameters are closer to measured data due to removing the invalid approximation. In addition, we have demonstrated its ability to study line mixing for the molecules mentioned above and our calculated results have significantly improved people’s previous knowledge of line mixing. In summary, with opening the door for a more accurate prediction of molecular spectra, the achievement of this project is far beyond our original expectations and has a profound impact both on line shape theories and on practical spectroscopic applications.
